sections.title: Export PDF images to another format
sections.context:
Export PDF images to another format
You can save every page (all text, images, and vector objects on a page) to an image format.
Choose
Convert
>

sections.title: Image format
sections.context:
Image format
> [Image Type]. You can also export each
image in a PDF to a separate image file.

sections.title: Rotate, move, delete, extract, or renumber
sections.context: Rotate, move, delete, extract, or renumber

sections.title: Rotate pages in a PDF
sections.context:
Rotate pages in a PDF
You can rotate all or select pages in a document. Rotation is based on 90-degree increments.
You can rotate pages using the rotate tools in the

sections.title: Page Thumbnails
sections.context:
Page Thumbnails
pane or
the
Rotate
option.
1.
Open the PDF in Acrobat, choose

sections.title: Organize pages.
sections.context:
Organize pages.
2.
From the left pane, specify the page range on which you want to apply the rotation.
Select the drop-down menu under

sections.title: PAGES SELECTED
sections.context:
PAGES SELECTED
, then select the appropriate
option. Alternatively, you can enter the page number you want to operate on.
3.
After specifying the page range, for Direction, select either Rotate page left for
counterclockwise 90deg rotation
or Rotate page rightdeg for clockwise 90deg rotation
.
4.
You can also apply the page rotation on a specific page by selecting the buttons in the
right pane.
Note:
To temporarily change your view of the page, from the hamburger menu
(Windows)
or the
View
menu (macOS), choose
View
>

sections.title: Rotate view
sections.context:
Rotate view
left
. The original page orientation is restored the next time you open the PDF.

sections.title: Extract pages from a PDF
sections.context:
Extract pages from a PDF
Extraction
is reusing selected pages of one PDF in a different PDF. Extracted pages include the
content and the form fields, comments, and links of the original document.
You can leave the extracted pages in the original document or remove them during
extraction.
Note:
Any bookmarks or article threadings associated with pages aren't extracted.
1.
Open the PDF in Acrobat. From the upper left, select

sections.title: Organize pages.
sections.context:
Organize pages.
2.
Specify the page range or the pages you want to extract. Select the drop-down menu
under

sections.title: PAGES SELECTED
sections.context:
PAGES SELECTED
, then select the appropriate option. Alternatively, you can
enter the page number you want to operate on.
3.
Select

sections.title: PAGE OPTIONS
sections.context:
PAGE OPTIONS
.
4.
In the dialog, select one or more of the following before you select
Extract
:
*
To remove the extracted pages from the original document, select
Delete

sections.title: pages after extracting
sections.context:
pages after extracting
.
*
To create a single-page PDF for each extracted page, select

sections.title: separate files
sections.context:
separate files
.
*
To keep the original pages intact and create a single PDF for the extracted
pages, deselect both options.
The extracted pages are placed in a new document.
Note:
The creator of a PDF document can set the security to prevent the extraction of pages.
To view the security settings for a document, choose

sections.title: Document properties
sections.context:
Document properties
from the
hamburger menu
(Windows) or
File
menu in macOS and then select the

sections.title: Security
sections.context:
Security
tab in
the dialog.

sections.title: Extract random pages from a PDF
sections.context:
Extract random pages from a PDF
You can also select and extract discontinuous pages from the page thumbnails in the right
navigation pane of Acrobat.
1.
Open the PDF in Acrobat. From the upper left, select

sections.title: Organize pages.
sections.context:
Organize pages.
2.
Specify the pages which you want to extract separated with a comma. For example, if
you want to extract pages 3 and 5, enter 3, 5 in the pages field under PAGES

sections.title: PAGE OPTIONS
sections.context:
PAGE OPTIONS
.
3.
In the dialog, select one or more of the following before you select
Extract
:
*
To remove the extracted pages from the original document, select
Delete

sections.title: pages after extracting
sections.context:
pages after extracting
.
*
To create a single-page PDF for each extracted page, select

sections.title: separate files
sections.context:
separate files
.
*
To keep the original pages intact and create a single PDF for the extracted
pages, deselect both options.
The extracted pages are placed in a new document.

sections.title: Split PDFs into multiple documents
sections.context:
Split PDFs into multiple documents
You can split one or more PDFs into multiple smaller PDFs. When splitting a PDF, you can
specify the split by the maximum number of pages, maximum file size, or top-level
bookmarks.
1.
Open the PDF in Acrobat. From the upper left, select

sections.title: Organize pages.
sections.context:
Organize pages.
2.
In the left pane, under

sections.title: PAGE OPTIONS
sections.context:
PAGE OPTIONS
, select
Split.
A command dialog appears for
the Split operation.
3.
In the

sections.title: Split By
sections.context:
Split By
list, select the criteria for dividing the document:

sections.title: Number of pages
sections.context:
Number of pages
Specify the maximum number of pages for each document in the split.

sections.title: File Size
sections.context:
File Size
Specify the maximum file size for each document in the split.

sections.title: Top-level Bookmarks
sections.context:
Top-level Bookmarks
If the document includes bookmarks, it creates one document for every top-level
bookmark.
4.
To specify a target folder for the split files and filename preferences, select
Output
Options
. Specify the options as needed, and then select
OK
.
5.
Select
Split
.

sections.title: Split multiple PDFs
sections.context:
Split multiple PDFs
1.
Open the PDF in Acrobat. From the upper left, select

sections.title: Organize pages.
sections.context:
Organize pages.
2.
In the left pane, under

sections.title: PAGE OPTIONS
sections.context:
PAGE OPTIONS
, select
Split.
A command dialog appears for
the Split operation.
3.
In the

sections.title: Split by
sections.context:
Split by
list, select the criteria for dividing the document:

sections.title: Number of pages
sections.context:
Number of pages
Specify the maximum number of pages for each document in the split.

sections.title: File Size
sections.context:
File Size
Specify the maximum file size for each document in the split.

sections.title: Top-level Bookmarks
sections.context:
Top-level Bookmarks
If the document includes bookmarks, it creates one document for every top-level
bookmark.
4.
To specify a target folder for the split files and filename preferences, select
Output
Options
. Specify the options as needed, and then select
OK
.
5.
Select

sections.title: Split multiple files
sections.context:
Split multiple files
. Select

sections.title: Add Files
sections.context:
Add Files
, and choose
Add Files, Add Folders
,
or

sections.title: Add Open Files
sections.context:
Add Open Files
. Select the files or folder, and then select
OK
. Select
Split
.

sections.title: Move or copy pages in a PDF
sections.context:
Move or copy pages in a PDF
To copy or move pages within a document, use the page thumbnails in the right navigation
pane or the document area. You can also transfer pages between documents using these
thumbnails. In the Organize Pages view, drag and drop thumbnails to rearrange pages, or
select a thumbnail and copy it as needed.

sections.title: Move or copy a page
sections.context:
Move or copy a page
1.
Open the PDF in Acrobat, and select

sections.title: Organize pages
sections.context:
Organize pages
.
The page thumbnails
are displayed in the Document area.
2.
Select one or more page thumbnails.
3.
Do one of the following:
*
To move a page, drag the corresponding page thumbnail to the new location.
A bar will appear to show the new position of the page thumbnail. The pages
will be renumbered.
*
To cut or copy a page, select the page, and then select the ellipsis icon
in the
context menu bar displayed next to it. Select
Cut
or
Copy
from the context
menu. Select between the page thumbnails where you want to paste the page.
A blue horizontal marker shows the selected location where you want to paste.
Select
Paste
from the context menu. You can paste the pages in another PDF as
well.
Note:
You can also move or copy pages by selecting the Page Thumbnails
button from
the right pane.

sections.title: Copy a page between two PDFs
sections.context:
Copy a page between two PDFs
1.
Open both PDFs and display them alongside each other.
To display the PDFs side by side, select
Window
from the hamburger
menu
(Windows) or the
Window
menu (macOS). Then select
Tile
>

sections.title: Vertically
sections.context:
Vertically
.
2.
Select

sections.title: Organize pages
sections.context:
Organize pages
.
The page thumbnails are displayed in the
Document area.
3.
Select the page thumbnail of the page you want to cut or copy. To select multiple
pages, press Ctrl (Windows) or command (macOS) and then select the pages. From
the page thumbnail context menu, select
Copy
.

sections.title: Page Thumbnails
sections.context:
Page Thumbnails
panel of the target PDF.

sections.title: Delete or replace pages in a PDF
sections.context:
Delete or replace pages in a PDF
You can replace an entire PDF page with another PDF page. Only the text and images on the
original page are replaced. Any interactive elements associated with the original page, such as
links and bookmarks, aren't affected. Likewise, bookmarks and links that may have been
previously associated with the replacement page don't carry over. Comments, however, are
carried over and are combined with any existing comments in the document.
After you delete or replace pages, it's a good idea to use the

sections.title: Reduce File Size
sections.context:
Reduce File Size
command to
rename and save the restructured document to the smallest possible file size.

sections.title: Delete multiple pages in a PDF
sections.context:
Delete multiple pages in a PDF
Note:
You can't undo the
Delete
command.
1.
Select

sections.title: Organize pages
sections.context:
Organize pages
. The page thumbnails are displayed in the
Document area.
2.
Specify the page thumbnail of the pages you want to delete and separate them with a
comma. For example, if you want to delete pages 3 and 5, enter 3, 5 in the pages field
under

sections.title: PAGES SELECTED
sections.context:
PAGES SELECTED
.  You can also choose from the options given in the drop-
down menu.
3.
In the left pane, select

sections.title: Delete pages
sections.context:
Delete pages
, and the select
OK
to confirm.

sections.title: Use Logical Page Numbers
sections.context:
Use Logical Page Numbers
in the

sections.title: Page Display
sections.context:
Page Display
panel of
the
Preferences
dialog box, you can enter a page number in parentheses to delete the
corresponding page. For example, if the first page in the document is numbered i, you can
enter (1) in the Enter Page Range list, and the page is deleted.

sections.title: Delete a page in a PDF
sections.context:
Delete a page in a PDF
1.
Select

sections.title: Organize pages
sections.context:
Organize pages
.
The page thumbnails are displayed in the
Document area.
2.
Select a page thumbnail of the page you want to delete. Then, select Delete
pages
from the contextual toolbar that appears next to the selected page
thumbnail.

sections.title: Replace pages in a PDF
sections.context:
Replace pages in a PDF
1.
Open the PDF that contains the pages you want to replace.
2.
Select

sections.title: Organize pages
sections.context:
Organize pages
.
The page thumbnails are displayed in the
Document area.
3.
In the left tools pane, select
Replace
. The file explorer window appears.
4.
Select the document containing the replacement pages.
5.
In the

sections.title: Replace Pages
sections.context:
Replace Pages
dialog box, under

sections.title: Original
sections.context:
Original
, enter the pages to be replaced in the
original document.
6.
In the

sections.title: Replace Pages
sections.context:
Replace Pages
dialog box, under

sections.title: Replacement
sections.context:
Replacement
, enter the first page of the
replacement page range. The last page is calculated based on the number of pages to
be replaced in the original document.
7.
Select
OK
.

sections.title: Replace pages between multiple PDFs
sections.context:
Replace pages between multiple PDFs
1.
Open the PDF that contains the pages you want to replace, and then open the PDF
that contains the replacement pages.
2.
Select

sections.title: Organize pages
sections.context:
Organize pages
for both PDFs.
The page thumbnails are displayed in
the Document area.

sections.title: Renumber pages in a PDF
sections.context:
Renumber pages in a PDF
The page numbers on the document pages don't always match the page numbers that appear
below the page thumbnails and in the right

sections.title: Page Navigation
sections.context:
Page Navigation
toolbar. Pages are numbered
with integers, starting with page 1 for the first page of the document. Because some PDFs may
contain front matter, such as a copyright page and table of contents, their body pages may
not follow the numbering shown in the right

sections.title: Page Navigation
sections.context:
Page Navigation
toolbar.
You can specify various numbering styles for a group of pages, for example, 1, 2, 3, or i, ii, iii, or
a, b, c. You can also customize the numbering system by adding a prefix. For example, pages
in Chapter 1 can be 1-1, 1-2, 1-3, and so on. Chapter 2 can have pages numbered as 2-1, 2-2, 2-3,
and so on.
Note:
Using the

sections.title: Number Pages
sections.context:
Number Pages
command affects only the page thumbnails on
the
Pages
panel. You can physically add new page numbers to a PDF using the headers and
footers feature.
1.
Select

sections.title: All tools
sections.context:
All tools
from the global bar. Then select

sections.title: Organize pages > Page labels.
sections.context:
Organize pages > Page labels.
2.
Specify a page range. (

sections.title: Selected
sections.context:
Selected
implies pages selected in the

sections.title: Page Thumbnails
sections.context:
Page Thumbnails
panel.)
3.
Select one of the following, and then select
OK
:

sections.title: Begin New Section
sections.context:
Begin New Section
: Starts a new numbering sequence. Choose a style from the pop-up
menu, and enter a starting page number for the section. Specify a
Prefix
, if desired.

sections.title: Extend Numbering Used In Preceding Section To Selected Pages
sections.context:
Extend Numbering Used In Preceding Section To Selected Pages
: Continues the numbering
sequence from previous pages without interruption.

sections.title: Edit Scanned PDFs
sections.context:
Edit Scanned PDFs
Editing a scanned PDF can be complicated if it includes low-quality text or images, non-
editable text, line breaks, or complex formatting. Other inhibiting factors include compatibility
issues, security restrictions, and large file sizes, which are more prevalent in PDFs created from
scanned images.
To streamline the process, consider the following best practices and guidelines before editing
a scanned document:
Check the accuracy of optical character recognition (OCR) output
. When you open a
scanned document, Acrobat
automatically runs OCR
in the background to make the
document editable. Before editing, review the document to ensure that the content is
accurate and complete. If necessary, rescan the document using the

sections.title: Recognize
sections.context:
Recognize
Text
tool to improve the output.

sections.title: Enhance image quality
sections.context:
Enhance image quality
. If the scanned PDF contains low-quality images, use the
Enhance

sections.title: Enhance camera image
sections.context:
Enhance camera image
feature to improve the quality of images before
attempting to edit the document. For more information, see
Scan documents to PDF
.

sections.title: Use the correct font and formatting
sections.context:
Use the correct font and formatting
. When editing the document, ensure that the font and
formatting of the edited text match the original document as closely as possible. If you don't
have the desired fonts on your computer, see
Add fonts to your computer
.

sections.title: Remove security restrictions
sections.context:
Remove security restrictions
. If the scanned PDF has security restrictions that prevent editing,
remove these restrictions before attempting to edit the document. To know how to remove
security from a PDF, see
Unlock a PDF
.

sections.title: Avoid editing complex elements
sections.context:
Avoid editing complex elements
. If the scanned PDF contains tables, graphs, or images,
avoid unnecessary edits that could alter the layout or formatting of these elements.

sections.title: Check for compatibility issues
sections.context:
Check for compatibility issues
. Ensure that the version of Adobe Acrobat you're using is
compatible with the scanned PDF. If you encounter compatibility issues, try updating Adobe
Acrobat. For more information, see
System requirements
.

sections.title: Save a backup copy
sections.context:
Save a backup copy
. Always save a backup copy of the original scanned PDF before making
any edits. Revert to the original document if any issues arise during the editing process.

sections.title: Recognize text on scanned PDF
sections.context:
Recognize text on scanned PDF
You can use the Scan & OCR tool to recognize text, change OCR language, and make all
pages editable in one go. To do so:

sections.title: In this file
sections.context:
In this file
.
3.
In the dialog that opens, select the pages that you want to apply text
recognition for and the language.
4.
Select

sections.title: Edit a scanned document
sections.context:
Edit a scanned document
1.
Open the scanned PDF file in Acrobat.
2.
From the global bar in the upper left, select
Edit
.
3.
Select the text element that you want to edit and start typing. The new text matches
the original font in your scanned PDF.
4.
From the upper-left corner, select the hamburger menu
(Windows) or File
(macOS)>
Save as
and enter a new name for your document.
Initially, the language is set to the default locale, and the other options are disabled. Any
changes to these settings are persisted and are applied when you edit the document.

sections.title: Enhance scanned file or camera images for
sections.context: Enhance scanned file or camera images for

sections.title: clear PDFs
sections.context:
clear PDFs
You can capture document photos with your smartphone and use the

sections.title: Enhance camera
sections.context:
Enhance camera
image
feature to create polished, clear, and compact PDFs without needing a standard
scanner. This feature addresses common issues in mobile-captured images, such as incorrect
perspectives, areas beyond boundaries, shadows, and inconsistent lighting. While it may not
eliminate all problems, it significantly improves the overall quality of your resulting PDF.

sections.title: Enhance camera image
sections.context:
Enhance camera image
1.
Open the photograph or image of the document in Acrobat.
2.
From the

sections.title: All tools
sections.context:
All tools
menu, select

sections.title: Scan & OCR
sections.context:
Scan & OCR
.
3.
From the left panel, select

sections.title: Enhance camera image
sections.context:
Enhance camera image
and then from the dialog that
opens, select
Enhance
.
4.
The image is enhanced and a PDF of the image is shown.
5.
(Optional) To further adjust the default enhancement level, drag the Adjust
enhancement level slider in the secondary toolbar.
